subject: Re: [junit] testing private methods
msgSnippet: ... I d say it s a violation of *principles*. It tests neither the public interface nor the private interface that we want tested, but rather an in-between
messageBody:
Brian Hurt wrote:

> Potiential solution- provide a skeletal inner class which "exports"
> private functions, like:
>
> public class example {
> private int foo(int x, int y);
> private boolean bar(double z);
>
> public class testprivates {
> public int testfoo(int x, int y) {
> return foo(x, y);
> }
> public boolean testbar(double z) {
> return bar(z);
> }
> }
> }
>
> This is definately a violation of design style, and arguably as
> unesthetic as the original solution if not worse. But I think it works (I
> haven't tried it- YMMV).

I'd say it's a violation of *principles*. It tests neither the public
interface nor the private interface that we want tested, but rather an
in-between throwaway interface. It's an extra layer of coding, clutter,
and potential bugs (it's highly vulnerable to cut-and-paste coding
errors, and might hide them for a while when direct testing would detect
them).

Back to my idea of implicit requirements - i think it is an implicit
requirement of unit testing that we test the real interface, not a
proxy. Feel free to disagree, as i'm often wrong.
